title: A successful `datalad get` can still look quite sad
body:
Here is the raw `git-annex get` call:

```
% git -C derivative/aggregate_fmri_timeseries annex get .
get sub-10/atlases/bold3Tp2/shen_fconn_atlas_150.nii.gz (from psydata...) 

  download failed: Not Found

  failed to download content
(from inm7-storage...) 
[INFO] Downloading 'https://datapub.fz-juelich.de/studyforrest/studyforrest.ria/7fc/d8812-d0fe-11e7-8db2-a0369f7c647e/annex/objects/2G/0J/MD5E-s32338--3cb12b68abd59160dffdf4830e1de8bb.nii.gz/MD5E-s32338--3cb12b68abd59160dffdf4830e1de8bb.nii.gz' into '.git/annex/tmp/MD5E-s32338--3cb12b68abd59160dffdf4830e1de8bb.nii.gz' 
(checksum...) ok
(recording state in git...)
```

So it tried one thing, failed, and then succeeded. Here is datalad:

```
% datalad get derivative/aggregate_fmri_timeseries/sub-10/atlases/bold3Tp2/shen_fconn_atlas_150.nii.gz
get(ok): derivative/aggregate_fmri_timeseries/sub-10/atlases/bold3Tp2/shen_fconn_atlas_150.nii.gz (file) [download failed: Not Found
failed to download content
download failed: Not Found
failed to download content
download failed: Not Found
failed to download content]
action summary:
  get (notneeded: 1, ok: 1)
```

So all worked, but the number of "failed" statements has doubled, and they shadow the happy core message quite effectively.

Due to the particular circumstances in my original run I  did not notice that each failing download attempt is also accompanied by ERROR log messages. So it is even worse.
